posts.com: Is obsidian md private? I heard it stores everything locally but I'm not sure if it's true.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: bump for interest

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294797
I did a bit of research myself. A lot of people seem to trust the developers of it and insist they don't access/read any of your files but it's still a gamble. It's not open source and there could easily be a backdoor for the developers to send themselves your data if they wanted regardless of if it stores files locally or not. Though I may just be paranoid.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294801
There's only two devs and they seem to have reasonable incentives to keep the project closed source, including focused development. https://forum.obsidian.md/t/open-sourcing-of-obsidian/1515/231

I scrolled through their privacy statements and EULA again, I did so when installing it a while back, they still look reassuring to me. I tried a foss alternative called Logseq and it started crashing on me on first boot up. You have to Shift + Enter to add a new line, plain Enter just makes everything a bullet point. Your post however convinced me to take some precautions and I installed https://tinywall.pados.hu/download.php to more easily block/unblock internet access, since it needs internet for updates, naturally. The program can be ran inside a sandbox too I think, it's worth either configuring a firewall or a sandbox for peace of mind because the program is fantastic.

Looking for seedy teenage romance manga. Series like Watari-kun no xx ga Houkai Sunzen, Gleipnir, Suzuka, etc.

Ideally completed series. Older works from the 90s or prior are welcome.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294232
What do you mean by "seedy"?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294247
Sordid and disreputable.

Examples as applied to the 3 named series:
Watari-kun - starts with MC being hounded by a selfish and aggressive girl, who wants to non-sexually pair with him because he was the only stability in her personal life. MC instead asks out another girl who is known to be the paragon of virtue; this is immediately revealed to be false, as she is secretly sexually aggressive due to having low self-esteem.

Gleipnir - starts with female blackmailing the MC into doing her bidding. Devolves into a soft love triangle when it's revealed that she is hunting her sister, who is the previous girlfriend of MC.

Suzuka - two hard-working athletes attempt a relationship, despite being a terrible fit for each other. MC is extremely low IQ and terrible at communication. Female slowly revealed to have a significantly bad personality and impossibly high standards. Disreputable actions, poor judgement, and push them into a long-term relationship that has severe negative externalities (and 1 very positive externality) on their friends, family, and related social institutions.

You image is vague. Do you want to use a laptop as the display of another PC which uses the keyboard of the laptop and a mouse connected to the laptop?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294135
I doubt it because the connections between the keyboard and screen are on the motherboard and sometimes they are propietary, meaning that if the laptop wasn't really built with that feature in mind, no equipment would be able to do this without having to disassemble your laptop.
However, there are alternatives. You use the desktop as a "server" by streaming the output to your laptop while sending input to it, which is pretty much what you want. The only problem I see is latency. Do you have your PCs in the same network? are the connections with decent speed (aka wired vs wireless, difference in standards Cat4 or 5, or Wifi 4, 5 or 6, etc)?
Lots of factors could affect the latency, but maybe it will be negligible. You won't know until you give it a try.
Research about VNC and/or RDP and similar.
They are ways to do what I am telling you.

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

But playing older games like Dota 2, DMC HD collection, or Minecraft did not shut down my PC at all. The shutdowns were instantly turning off; no error or blue screens. It only happened when playing a game, never when working on my desktop or doing other stuff. I checked event viewer and only saw "the previous shutdown was unexpected". This led to me believing it must be a hardware issue and not a software one, or else a log would show up I thought.

So knowing this, I replaced my PSU, thinking it was going bad, with a 1000w gold cert PSU and it still shut down. I changed my storage to an m.2 drive, I changed my outlet choice, changed my power extender, changed my fans, cleaned out the PC, reinstalled my drivers, reset bios, nothing worked. I came to a point where I just rebuilt the entire PC and did an entire fresh install of windows 11. The only single part now in my PC that is from my old one is my AMD 6900xt GPU. Everything else is completely brand new parts. So I booted up Valheim on my pretty much brand new PC and it shut down in 5 minutes while talking on discord while playing. It is easily replicated too.

So it now comes down to either being the GPU or my apartment is simply haunted. I did try changing the outlets before and just now I tried changing to a completely different room in my apartment with another outlet and it still shut down in the intro to Valheim. I have owned this GPU for about 1.5 years and I have no idea how to check if the GPU is failing, but I never had these shutdowns when I first got it. I don't really remember when these shutdowns started occurring either, maybe a few months ago. Does anyone have any ideas? I don't have any other GPU to test with and I am trying to find an excuse not to spend 1000$ on a GPU.

posts.com: I'm having booting problems with my SSD. If I reinstall Windows on a new disk, delete the c drive and then clone the old c drive onto it, would it boot like normal? Pic unrelated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294099
Windows is installed in C:\Windows.
So deleting the drive deletes the new install.
And cloning the old drive will give you an unbootable system again.

You'll have to manually move your files from the old install to the new install on the new disk.

- boot windows 10 USB

If you were on Windows 10, DISM. But you're not, so repair install
>I reinstall Windows on a new disk, delete the c drive and then clone the old c drive onto it, would it boot like normal?
This is an incredibly perverse and complicated way to achieve the same thing as just installing windows to the C drive. So just install windows to the c drive, and it will move all your old stuff to \windows.old\

You probably shouldn't reinstall windows then. Try getting your OS booted in safe mode, then running SFC.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294620
>the file size of the end video is bigger than original file
That's because it's re-encoding the video.
If you tweak the encoder settings, you could get the size smaller, but the quality would be worse, as it always happens when encoding lossy to lossy.

You can use avidemux in copy mode to cut video without re-encoding.
You'll be limited to starting the cut on a keyframe, but the end can be anywhere.

To use it:
0- Make sure Video Output and Audio Output are set to Copy.
1- Drag and drop your video in the editor.
2- Click on "Go to next keyframe" (>> icon) until you reach the point you want to start the cut.
3- Click on "Set end marker" (-| B icon).
4- Press delete on your keyboard.
5- Sweep the timeline and find the point where you want to end the cut.
6- Click on "Set start marker" (|-A- icon).
7- Press delete on your keyboard.
8- Choose your output format.
If you want a webm, the codecs have to be VP8/Vorbis or VP9/Opus.
9- Click on save video in the upper left.

>>1294598
If you only want to game (no machine learning stuff), I would go for the RX 6600 instead.
It goes down to $200 on sale and is ~30% better than the RTX 3050.
$360 for a 3050 is ludicrous.

The B450 motherboard might give you trouble if the BIOS isn't up-to-date.
You should go for a B550 instead, or else you may need to borrow an older processor to flash a newer BIOS.
Plus you get PCIe 4.0 with the B550 while the B450 is only 3.0.

Consider the Ryzen 5 4500 or 5600 for the CPU.
They're better value than the 5600x.

The RAM is fine, but a non-RGB model with the same speed and CL would be cheaper.

The Corsair RM850x is a great PSU, but unless you're planning to upgrade to more power-hungry CPU/GPU, you should go for a 650W or even 550W model.
That would be cheaper, and PSUs are most efficient around the 50% mark.
Since your system would barely use 250W at full load, it's better to use a lower power PSU.
Just make sure to pick one that's tier A or B on this list (RM850x is tier A):
https://cultists.network/140/psu-tier-list/

How can you contaminate a jury pool by quoting the law and the constitution? Prosecutors don't like the idea that you know about jury nullification, but it's just a fancy name for the logical consequence of the jury's verdict being de-jure correct. If there could be a "wrong" verdict there'd be no need for a jury because the judge would determine what the correct verdict was and the jury would have to return to the same correct verdict or be in contempt of court. Ergo there can be no such thing as a "wrong verdict", so jury nullification is de-jure legal, and talking about it is merely mentioning true facts about the law.

You were doing so well.

The winning conditions are in an array so you can use a nested loop (or some kind of lambda function) to test them all without writing a bunch of repetitive code

function testVictoryCondition(c, b) { //Condition, Board
p = "" // see note
for i in c {
if (p == "") { p = b[c]; continue;}
if (b[c] != p) return false; }
return p // this will be false if the whole line is full of empty squares, assuming empty squares are falsy}

function testAllVictoryConditions (C, b) {
for c in C { if (winner=testVictoryCondition(c,b)) {declareWinner(winner);}}
// no winner :(
}


* note: this is a common problem with for-loop patterns: you want to do something different for the first iteration to set everything up, but you can't do it outside the loop because the variables are only in-scope inside the loop. Checking if you're initialised or not is one solution; every solution is kinda bad.

If verbosely using the 8 if-statements is not mandatory, here is a more compact way to check for a win:

function isWin() {
return winningCondition.some(
(condition) => {
let line = condition.map((idx)=>document.getElementById(boardIndex[idx]).textContent);
return (line[0] != "" && line.every((x)=>x==line[0]))
}
)
}

To check if there is a draw, keep track of the amount of turns. Nine turns without a win is a draw.

I have a small tplink LS1005G, and I cant connect almost anything on it, but a laptop with the r8168 driver refuses to work at all, checked cables, changed cables, make a manually configuration, copy the values from another working machine with the same configuration.
The same machines worked fine before.

The usual setup was
PC1----------------------|
PC2----------------------|
MODEM/ROUTER...|-------------------LS1005G
or
PC1----------------------|
PC2----------------------|-------------------LS1005G

any of the former worked out, so I don'k know
why it changed and it does make his job,
Thanks anon!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1293798
>LS1005G
You probably have a cable with a damaged pair, so the switch and the NIC think they can do gigabit (which uses all four pairs), but then it doesn't work.

Try a brand-new cable, or force the driver to not autonegotiate but instead select 100 Base TX (which uses only two pairs).

posts.com: Why does 'do shell script "open -a /Applications/Brave\\ Browser.app --args --incognito"' correctly open ONE window while 'do shell script "open -a /Applications/Brave\\ Browser.app --args -tor"' opens two windows? Is there any way to fix this?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294263
>-tor
Brave's manual doesn't list this one at all, but wouldn't it be "--tor"?
Unix convention is one minus for single-letter arguments ("-o", "-t", "-v") and two minuses for multiple-letter arguments ("--sparse", "--verbose"), and a lot of the command-line parsing libraries make doing anything else difficult or impossible.
